docs.lead_paragraph: White students who showed higher levels of racial prejudice on tests meant to gauge those attitudes had a harder time concentrating after talking with a black researcher than did their less-biased peers, a new study has found. The study, which involved 59 students and was published last week in the journal Psychological Science, says the performance of biased students on a task that measured ''executive function'' skills dropped by almost two-thirds after conversations with a black researcher but not after conversations with a white researcher.
docs.abstract: Dartmouth College researcher Dr Jennifer A Richeson and Princeton University researcher Dr J Nicole Shelton publish findings in journal Psychological Science that show individuals who are racially prejudiced have harder time concentrating after conversation with black interviewer; contend strain of veiling their prejudice depletes their available energy (S)
docs.snippet: White students who showed higher levels of racial prejudice on tests meant to gauge those attitudes had a harder time concentrating after talking with a black researcher than did their less-biased peers, a new study has found.     The study, which...

docs.lead_paragraph: Overweight Americans are eating their way to an early grave in more ways than people realize. While many may know that excess pounds raise the risk of heart disease, hypertension, diabetes, stroke, arthritis, gallbladder disease and other debilitating and sometimes fatal health problems, now a host of cancers can be firmly added to the list. No longer is the relationship of excess weight to cancer restricted to just a few cancers like breast and uterine, influenced by hormones produced in body fat.

headline.main: Another Study Finds a Link Between Excess Weight and Cancer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column reports sweeping link between almost all cancers and excess body weight; study, led by Dr Eugenia E Calle and published in New England Journal of Medicine, finds direct relationship between degree to which person is overweight and their risk of death from cancer; heaviest men had death rates from cancer that were 52% or higher and women had death rates 62% or higher than those of individuals with normal weight; recently updated cancer society guidelines are given; graph (L)
docs.snippet: Overweight Americans are eating their way to an early grave in more ways than people realize. While many may know that excess pounds raise the risk of heart disease, hypertension, diabetes, stroke, arthritis, gallbladder disease and other...

docs.lead_paragraph: Thunderstorms kill twice as many men as women, a new study has found. The gender gap is biggest for lightning strikes; 85 percent of those killed are men. But it also applies to deaths from flooding by storms, tornadoes and high winds, according to the study, which was presented last week at a conference on safety held by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
docs.abstract: University of Pittsburgh researcher Dr Thomas J Songer presents study at federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention conference that shows significant gender gap in deaths related to thunderstorms; 85% of those individuals killed by lightning are male; suggests men may participate more in outdoor activites than women; conflicting safety advice about precautions one should take during storms may be cause of some deaths; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Thunderstorms kill twice as many men as women, a new study has found.    The gender gap is biggest for lightning strikes; 85 percent of those killed are men. But it also applies to deaths from flooding by storms, tornadoes and high winds, according...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: As a young physician in the 1960's, Dr. Floyd E. Bloom was part of the team from the National Institutes of Health that uncovered the principles behind the drugs that are now used to treat depression. Since then, he has been the director of behavioral neurobiology at the Salk Institute, the chairman of the neuropharmacology department at the Scripps Research Institute and the chief of the neuropharmacology laboratory at the National Institute of Mental Health.

headline.main: A Zealous Quest for Chemicals to Heal Ailing Brains

docs.abstract: Interview with renowned physician-scientist Floyd Bloom discusses career and accomplishments beginning with his early relationship with medicine through his pharmacist father; Bloom worked at National Institutes of Health when basics of psychopharmacology were discovered and supplied hope for those suffering from depression; photo (L)
docs.snippet: As a young physician in the 1960's, Dr. Floyd E. Bloom was part of the team from the National Institutes of Health that uncovered the principles behind the drugs that are now used to treat depression.    Since then, he has been the director of...

docs.lead_paragraph: I have a patient with congestive heart failure. Tom is a wispy-thin man with a predilection for vintage suits who had a heart defect surgically repaired 50 years ago, when he was 5. The surgeon performed a finger valvuloplasty: he used his little finger to free up the motion of a congenitally rigid valve. The procedure was successful, but over the years, the valve leaked and that eventually caused Tom's heart to weaken and enlarge.

headline.main: Buying Time: Doctors Debate the Ethics of Care and Cost

docs.abstract: Doctors are being forced to enter ethical debate about how, when and who should receive costly medical treatments such as pacemakers and implantable defibrillators; factors, such as patient's age and degree of illness, along with cost, are weighed sometimes more heavily than actual effectiveness of treatment; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Listening to music with violent lyrics increases aggressive thoughts and feelings, says a study published yesterday. But when lyrics with humor are added, the effect seems to be diluted. Though the record industry has adopted a system to rate violence in lyrics, most research on violence in media has focused on television, movies and music videos, the study's lead researcher, Dr. Craig A. Anderson, a psychologist at Iowa State University, wrote in The Journal of Personality and Social Psychology.

headline.main: Sour Notes in Songs of Violence

docs.abstract: Iowa State University psychologist Dr Craig A Anderson publishes study in Journal of Personality and Social Psychology that finds listening to music with violent lyrics increases aggressive thoughts and behavior; study contradicts idea that violent songs create cathartic effects and reduce aggression; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Listening to music with violent lyrics increases aggressive thoughts and feelings, says a study published yesterday. But when lyrics with humor are added, the effect seems to be diluted.    Though the record industry has adopted a system to rate...

keywords.value: JOURNAL OF PERSONALITY AND SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY

docs.lead_paragraph: Recent tests of a variety of ginkgo biloba supplements have found that their quality has dropped sharply since a similar survey was conducted in 1999, a new study reports. The survey, which was done by Consumerlabs.com, found that only about one in five of the ginkgo products tested conformed to specifications used in European clinical studies. (No American standards have been issued.)
docs.abstract: Recent study by Consumerlabs.com, company that analyzes dietary supplements and herbal products, finds disparity in levels of biobalide found in many US marketed Ginkgo Biloba compared with European made supplement; contends that drop in memory effectiveness of ginkgo biloba for users in US is related to deficient biobalide; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Recent tests of a variety of ginkgo biloba supplements have found that their quality has dropped sharply since a similar survey was conducted in 1999, a new study reports.     The survey, which was done by Consumerlabs.com, found that only about one...

docs.lead_paragraph: Every athlete, every fitness enthusiast has heard the advice to drink plenty of water. Drink as much as you can. Don't wait until you are thirsty. By then it may be too late. You may be seriously dehydrated, risking dizziness, collapse, even death. ''Stay ahead of your thirst,'' athletes and would-be athletes are told. But now USA Track & Field, the national governing body for track and field, long-distance running and race walking, says that advice is wrong. In what it calls a major revision of its guidelines, the organization says endurance athletes, who may be consuming huge amounts of water over the course of a long event, may risk seizures, respiratory failure and even death from drinking too much.

headline.main: New Advice To Runners: Don't Drink The Water

docs.abstract: Dr David E Martin, Georgia State University (Atlanta) exercise physiologist, and Dr Tim Noakes, University of Cape Town (South Africa) researcher, publish advisory statement for International Marathon Medical Directors Association in which they outline potential harm in excess water intake, particularly while exercising; excess water can lead to hyponatremia when water dilutes blood and causes sodium levels to drop; new guidelines suggest athletes should drink water when they are thirsty, not at every opportunity (M)
docs.snippet: Every athlete, every fitness enthusiast has heard the advice to drink plenty of water. Drink as much as you can. Don't wait until you are thirsty. By then it may be too late. You may be seriously dehydrated, risking dizziness, collapse, even death....
